title: Permissionator
subtitle: Linux chmod calculator for generating, converting and verifying file permissions

what.aboutChmod: The chmod command changes file mode bits on Unix and Linux systems. File permissions control who can read, write, or execute a file. They are expressed in octal digits (like 755) or symbolic form (like u=rwx,g=rx,o=rx). The first digit in a four-digit mode denotes special bits: setuid (4), setgid (2), and sticky (1).

commonPresets.description: Owner read/write; private files like SSH keys
Owner read/write; everyone else read; typical text files
Owner full control; private scripts or directories
Owner rwx, others rx; common for directories and executables

cards.heading: Octal basics
cards.description: Each role gets a digit: read=4, write=2, execute=1. Sum to get the digit: e.g., rwx = 7, rw- = 6, r-x = 5, r-- = 4. Common modes: 644 for files, 755 for directories.

cards.heading: Symbolic form
cards.description: Use letters for users (u), group (g), others (o) with +, -, or =. For example: chmod u=rw,g=r,o= file.txt sets read/write for owner, read for group, and no access for others.

cards.heading: Special bits
cards.description: setuid runs executables with the owner's privileges; setgid runs with the group's privileges; sticky prevents users from deleting others' files in shared directories (e.g., /tmp).
